title: Tom Biggs
text:
Tom Biggs (born 22 August 1984) is an English former <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> footballer, most recently he played for <a href="Worcester%20Warriors">Worcester Warriors</a>. His usual position was at <a href="Wing%20%28rugby%20union%29">wing</a>. Biggs featured in the <a href="Zurich%20Premiership">Zurich Premiership</a>, <a href="Powergen%20Cup">Powergen Cup</a> and <a href="European%20Rugby%20Cup">European Cup</a>. He has a twin brother
Biggs had not played any club rugby before joining the Yorkshire U18s, having only played with his school team at <a href="Hymers%20College">Hymers College</a>. Biggs was spotted by the then Tykes Academy boss <a href="Stuart%20Lancaster%20%28rugby%29">Stuart Lancaster</a> and was asked to join the Tykes' Academy side.
Before the 2004–05 <a href="Zurich%20Premiership">Zurich Premiership</a> season, Biggs was considering a part-time rugby career with <a href="National%20Division%20Two">National Division Two</a> team <a href="Harrogate%20RUFC">Harrogate</a>, having failed to make an appearance in the <a href="Leeds%20Tykes">Leeds Tykes</a> first team. At the time, he was working in a cinema and in a pea factory to supplement his life as a business student at <a href="Leeds%20Metropolitan%20University">Leeds Metropolitan University</a>, but by the end of the season he had collected a <a href="Powergen%20Cup">Powergen Cup</a> winners medal.
He had been recalled by Tykes coach <a href="Phil%20Davies">Phil Davies</a> on the eve of the season as the club were forced to call on all their resources when faced with an injury crisis with <a href="Phil%20Christophers">Phil Christophers</a>, <a href="Diego%20Albanese">Diego Albanese</a>, <a href="Tim%20Stimpson">Tim Stimpson</a> and <a href="Iain%20Balshaw">Iain Balshaw</a> all unable to play. Biggs was included in the pre-season warm up games and was picked in the starting line up for the opening game of the season against <a href="Gloucester%20Rugby">Gloucester Rugby</a> on 5 September 2004, making his full debut in a 16–21 defeat at <a href="Headingley">Headingley</a>.
Biggs also featured in the next game against <a href="Leicester%20Tigers">Leicester Tigers</a>, scoring a try in a 20–42 defeat. He was first to react to a <a href="Gordon%20Ross%20%28rugby%20player%29">Gordon Ross</a> cross field kick and chipped on ahead of <a href="Austin%20Healey">Austin Healey</a> to collect the ball and evade the cover tackle to touch down. The try was later short-listed for the <a href="Gillette%20%28brand%29">Gillette</a> Try of the season at the <a href="Zurich%20Awards">Zurich Awards</a>.
Biggs made a total of 21 appearances in the 2004–05 season, helping the Tykes to avoid relegation from the Zurich Premiership with another try against Leicester in a 23–22 victory at Headingley. He ended his debut season with a place in the Tykes' Powergen Cup final against <a href="Bath%20Rugby">Bath Rugby</a>, collecting his first winners medal in a 20–12 win. He was chosen ahead of <a href="Argentina">Argentine</a> wing <a href="Diego%20Albanese">Diego Albanese</a> in the Tykes' side for the <a href="Twickenham%20Stadium">Twickenham</a> clash.
After his first season, he was selected for the England team in the <a href="International%20Rugby%20Board">IRB</a> U21s Championship in Argentina and was involved in the U21s' <a href="Six%20Nations%20Championship">Six Nations</a> campaign, playing in their final clash with <a href="Scotland">Scotland</a>. He ended last season as the club's top try scorer and was voted Player of the Year.
Biggs, who was close to being selected for the <a href="England%20Saxons">England Saxons</a> last summer, committed himself to the Tykes until 2009. He missed three months of the National Division One 2006/7 season, following a shoulder surgery that he suffered in September 2006. He had an operation to repair torn cartilage and a ligament, but returned to action in January 2007 as a replacement against Nottingham.
Biggs moved to the <a href="Newcastle%20Falcons">Newcastle Falcons</a> on a one-year contract for the 2009–10 season. He was also called into the <a href="England%20Saxons">England Saxons</a> squad to face <a href="Italy%20A%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Italy A</a> in <a href="Ragusa%2C%20Italy">Ragusa</a>, Sicily on 9 February 2008. On 17 February 2010, it was announced that Biggs had signed a three-year deal to play for Bath.
On 10 October 2013, Biggs was set for a cross-code switch to <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> to join <a href="Hull%20F.C.">Hull F.C.</a> in the <a href="Super%20League">Super League</a>. But on 4 April 2014, Hull F.C. announced they called off the deal to sign Tom Biggs. Instead, Biggs signed for local rivals <a href="Worcester%20Warriors">Worcester Warriors</a>, who compete in the <a href="RFU%20Championship">RFU Championship</a> from the 2014–15 season.
On 16 October 2017 Biggs announced his retirement from rugby on medical advice.
